I think that if you look at Connecticut in particular, I think that there were two things happening.
One is that the vote - the Lieberman defeat - reflects an overall discontent that most voters in the country have -62 percent of them have - with the way that the war is going in Iraq.

And then, I think specifically for Democrats, what you saw was a reaction to Democratic grassroots voters being tired of Democratic politicians who are willing to walk away from the party in a way that they consider gratuitous.
I think that people in Connecticut thought that Lieberman was… It's one thing if you have different views than the Democratic party and you stand - you know, and there's a principle behind it.

But I think that people thought that Lieberman gratuitously would walk away from the party because he thought it was good for him politically, nationally, and there's now a price to be paid if you do that.
How much of this, Robert, is change for change sake, do you think?
I think actually there is - there's actually a fair amount of principle involved and I tend to actually agree, generally speaking, with what Jennifer just said.

I think in the context of the Tuesday races, the Cynthia McKinney one is sort of an outlier because - I mean, this is the second time that she'd lost a primary in the last four years and her controversies are well known.

But in both Connecticut with Lieberman and in Michigan with Schwartz, you had cases where the grassroots of the parties, which are, basically, slightly more to the extreme of the broader party - in other words, the conservatives are the base part of the Republican party, the liberals are the base part of the Democrats - they basically said that they don't want Republicans in name only in the Republican side and Democrats in name only - DINOs, as it were - on the Democrat side.

And it also has to be looked at in the context where grassroots organizations like the Club for Growth - which really focus on economic issues and lesser government - they have been running candidates against incumbents at the state level, particularly in Pennsylvania, and they had a number of victories knocking off incumbent members of the legislature.
So I think you're starting to see a little bit more of a wave of the bases of the party trying to instill certain kind of principled opposition and adherence to principle positions, on both parties.
